newsitem.title: USA: Canada LPGs fall on concerns of weaker demand.
newsitem.headline: Canada LPGs fall on concerns of weaker demand.

text.p: Canadian liquefied petroleum gas prices (LPG) fell in moderate trade this week as suppliers cut offers in anticipation of slower springtime demand, traders said.
In the eastern region of Sarnia, propane fell 1.25 cents a gallon, with offers 41.25 cents. The premium over U.S. Belvieu propane shrank to 1.50 cents.
"The decrease in differential suggests the market thinks the winter season's on its last legs," one trader said.
In winter, Sarnia propane stays at least three-cents higher than Belvieu material.
Western suppliers at Edmonton dropped offers 1.50 cents to 32.50 cents, amid this weeks weaker U.S. prices and concerns that inventories might build.
Between 80 percent and 85 percent of Canadian LPG is sold through contracts, largely to domestic and U.S. buyers.
Offers for normal butane in Sarnia fell one cent to 43.50 cents, while Edmonton field butane eased 0.75 cents.
